description: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS)(1) –Electrical stimulator with electrodes that attach to the skin –Portable units powered by batteries allow for use during functional tasks and ADLs –Desired outcome is usually a lessening of pain signals for relief

Parameters of “standard” TENS devices(1) –Administer biphasic pulsed currents –Pulse durations range from 50 to 1,000 microseconds (µsec) –Pulse frequencies range from 1 to 250 pulses per second (pps) –Pulse patterns are typically continuous or burst

Common terminology –Pulse amplitude – milliamps (mA)(2) –Pulse duration –µsec(3) –Pulse frequency -Pulses per second (pps)(1) -Hertz (Hz)(1) -Note: Hz and pps are equivalent units of frequency (1 Hz = 1 pps) –Waveform – “A visual representation of the flow of electric current through a conductor on an amplitude-time  plot”(1) –Biphasic pulsatile current(1) -A type of waveform -Consists of a positive and a negative phase –Low-frequency  TENS is generally considered less than 10 Hz(3) –High-frequency  TENS is generally considered greater than 50 Hz(3)
reimbursement: Clinicians are advised to check with insurance providers prior to the administration of TENS. In the United States, only TENS units approved by the U.S. FDA are covered. Medical insurance providers might require that the patient rent the TENS unit (versus purchasing the unit) and might also limit the length of time a patient can keep the rental unit. Reimbursement may depend on chronicity, etiology, and severity of pain. A physician’s prescription is usually required for reimbursement Indications for device/equipment
contraindications precautions to test: History-taking  and examination procedures depend largely on the underlying condition and reason for referral. The information listed below is meant to serve as a guide/overview. Clinicians should supplement or modify the recommendations listed below as indicated and appropriate given the unique circumstances of the patient

contraindications precautions to examina: History-taking  and examination procedures depend largely on the underlying condition and reason for referral. The information listed below is meant to serve as a guide/overview. Clinicians should supplement or modify the recommendations listed below as indicated and appropriate given the unique circumstances of the patient

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: What is the current reason for referral?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management will vary depending on the specific underlying condition; document any reported diagnostic tests, surgeries and other therapeutic interventions, and/or hospital stays
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective? Is the patient comfortable with the medications he or she is taking? Is the patient looking for an alternative approach to pain relief?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Diagnostic tests will depend largely on clinical history, presenting signs and symptoms, and suspected underlying condition
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments (e.g., TENS) were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any reported aggravating or easing factors
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling); ask patient to describe his or her perceived functional limitations
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or the Numeric Rating Scale (NRS), a 010scale,  to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to condition as applicable. If patient complains of nighttime pain, inquire whether the pain wakes the patient when he or she moves or while lying still. Is nighttime waking dependent on position? Does patient report daytime fatigue related to sleep disturbance?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise? Any past or present use of supplemental oxygen or mechanical ventilation? Does the patient smoke? Obtain results of recent pulmonary function tests where relevant Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, pregnancy complications, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Be sure to ask the patient directly regarding contraindications/precautions to use of TENS
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient work or attend school?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Inquire about limitations with self-care,  home management, work, community, and leisure
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Evaluation procedures should be modified according to the patient’s age, diagnosis, and any unique circumstances; the information listed below is meant to serve as a guide only. Complete a general evaluation as indicated and appropriate
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient utilize any assistive or adaptive devices? Are they appropriate and used correctly?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess the patient’s balance in sitting and stance as indicated. Use a standardized tool such as the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) or Functional Reach Test as indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess for signs of diminished circulation. Check peripheral pulsesAssess peripheral nerve mobility if nerve involvement is suspected or indicated by the patient’s chief complaint. Assess motor and/or sensory distribution of cranial and peripheral nerves as indicatedAssess for faulty body mechanics that might be contributing to the patient’s pain
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess functional mobility as indicated by underlying condition. Standardized tests that can be used include the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, the FIM, the five times sit to stand test (FTSTST), and gait speed(measured using the 10-meter  walk test)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Complete a thorough gait assessment as indicated by reason for referral. The Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) can be used to assess safety during ambulationAssess joint integrity as indicated by symptoms and reason for referralEvaluate motor function and muscle tone as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Complete a thorough strength assessment throughout with a particular focus on the area where TENS is to be applied
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect skin for any signs of irritation or breakdown before and after treatment(1)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess the patient’s general postureComplete a thorough ROM assessment with a particular focus on the area where TENS is to be applied
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexesComplete an ADL assessment as indicated. Use a standardized tool such as the Barthel Index or FIM as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Complete a thorough sensory assessment (e.g., light touch, temperature, pinprick) of the area where TENS is to be applied
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: -pressure algometry or dolorimetry – device used to obtain pain threshold and tolerance(23)  -Neuropathic Pain Scale (NPS) – an instrument that assesses specific qualities of neuropathic pain, such as intense, sharp, hot, dull, cold, deep, and superficial. There is also an item on the NPS to assess the overall “unpleasantness” of the pain(21) -Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) – used to assess the effects of pain on the lives of patients(21) -McGill Pain Questionnaire (MPQ) – a self-report  questionnaire. Users select words from lists that best describe their pain. Numerical values are then assigned to the words -analgesic intake
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Complete a cognitive assessment as indicated and appropriate –The patient will need to be able to place the electrodes on his or her body appropriately and set the device as instructed (if used at home/independently) –Is the patient able to inform the provider if the electrical stimulation is beginning to feel uncomfortable?(1)

other: Patients who need this device or those with a diagnosis for which this device is used might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies ›Diagnosis/need for device/equipment:  Pain is the primary indication for TENS; please see Indications for device/ equipment , above, for more details
contraindications precautions.general: Pain is the primary indication for TENS; please see Indications for device/

assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to other disciplines (e.g., occupational therapy, psychiatry) as indicated and appropriate. Consider referral to pain management clinic for chronic/refractory pain
other considerations: Ultra-low-frequencyTENS  (ULF-TENS)  can be used to assist in the construction of a neuromuscular lingual device to reduce the signs and symptoms of temporomandibular joint dysfunction (TMD). ULF-TENS  helps to decrease the muscles’ electrical resting hyperactivity and increase the interocclusal distance, allowing for the necessary conditions to fabricate an oral cavity device(45)

Perceptual threshold of touch(8) –A new application of TENS is to objectively measure the perceptual threshold of touch (PTT). Hand dexterity and grasp function are important for work-related activities and ADLs. A person’s ability to accurately perceive touch pressure enables proper object manipulation and other functional dexterity tasks. Thus, it would be beneficial to clinicians and researchers to be able to measure impaired PTT to assess progress and outcomes –Authors of an observational study (N = 346 adults) in Sweden found that TENS objectively measured PTT (in mA) in the hands and feet. The goal was to establish norms for PTT in adults, as well as to assess if age, sex, handedness, right/left side, height, weight, or BMI had any influence on PTT -3.75 mA (range 2.50–7.25  mA) was the median for PTT in the hands, whereas PTT in the feet could not be established due to extreme variability about the median. Advancing age, male sex, and the right side were associated with increased PTT

Authors of a randomized double-blind  crossover study (N = 30 persons) in Canada found that TENS is effective at reducing experimentally induced pain in younger individuals (age 26±5), but did not reduce pain in older adults (age 67±5)(36)

Transelectrical nerve acupuncture stimulation (TEAS) can provide some positive effects on maintaining orthostatic tolerance during short-term,  head-down  bed rest when applied to the PC6 acupressure point for at least 30 minutes daily(37) –Based on a study in China involving 14 male subjects. Patients were randomized: TEAS group and control group –Plasma volume-regulating  hormones, plasma volume, and heart rate were measured before and after treatment –Intervention consisted of patients lying in supine with headdown at minus 6° from horizontal. Patients were asked to be completely bedridden for 4 days (i.e., eating, washing, defecation, urination). TEAS was applied to the PC6 acupressure point for 30 minutes daily –Results at the end of the treatment indicate that TEAS treatment improved orthostatic tolerance as well as reduced cardiac deconditioning compared to the control group
treatment summary: Acute pain –Authors of a 2009 Cochrane review of 12 RCTs (N = 919) without meta-analysis found insufficient evidence to draw conclusions regarding the efficacy of TENS in the management of acute pain(9)
Chronic pain –Authors of a 2008 Cochrane review of 25 RCTs (N = 1,281) without meta-analysis found that evidence was lacking to determine the efficacy of TENS in the management of chronic pain(7)
Cancer pain –Authors of a 2012 Cochrane review of 3 RCTs (N = 88) without meta-analysis found insufficient evidence to determine the efficacy of TENS in the management of cancer pain(10)

Chronic low back pain –Authors of a 2008 Cochrane review of 4 RCTs (N = 585) without meta-analysis found that TENS does not appear to be effective in the management of chronic low back pain(11) –No significant difference in pain level was found in patients with chronic low back pain in a study that compared adjusted TENS amplitude to fixed TENS amplitude(32)

Neck pain –Authors of an RCT (N = 64 females with posterior neck pain) found that TENS was not as effective as interferential current therapy (IFC) for relieving upper trapezius tension in computer users with chronic nonspecific neck discomfort(24) -Treatment with TENS or IFC occurred on 3 consecutive days -Muscle relaxation was assessed using EMG. Pain was assessed with a V AS -A significant pain decrease was found in both groups; however, only the IFC group had a clinically important improvement –Authors of a single-blind  RCT (N = 105 patients with myofascial pain syndrome and an upper trapezius myofascial trigger point) in Sri Lanka found that TENS treatment improved pain intensity and cervical ROM significantly more than IFC treatment(39) -Participants were randomized to one of 3 groups: TENS (8 times for 4 weeks), IFC (8 times for 4 weeks), or control. Each group also received standard care -The TENS group showed the greatest improvement in pain and cervical ROM (extension, lateral flexion to the contralateral side, and rotation to the ipsilateral side) after the 8th treatment –Electric point TENS might improve pain, but not cervical ROM, in patients with upper trapezius trigger points(12) -Based on an RCT (N = 78) in the United Kingdom comparing electric point TENS or sham TENS –Burst-type  TENS might improve cervical ROM and pain in patients with upper trapezius trigger points(13) -Based on an RCT(N = 76) in Spain who received burst-type  TENS or sham TENS –Cervical spinal mobilization and TENS were found equally effective in reducing numbness, tingling, and pain in patients with cervical radiculopathy(14) -Based on an RCT (N = 75) in India who received cervical mobilization and isometric neck exercises, heat therapy and isometric neck exercises, or heat therapy and TENS

Other musculoskeletal pain –Authors of a 2009 Cochrane review of 18 RCTs (N = 813) with meta-analysis  found that the efficacy of TENS alone or in combination with other modalities for the management of osteoarthritic knee pain could not be determined based on the available body of evidence(15) –Authors of an RCT (N = 70) investigated if TENS could help male athletes perform better during the first phase of rehabilitation (0–4 weeks) and at follow-up  (14 weeks) after ACL reconstruction surgery(43) -Athletes were randomized into 2 groups: the first group received pre-determined  exercise and mobilization regimen plus high-frequency  TENS for 35 minutes a day for 4 weeks (20 sessions) and the second group received only the predetermined exercise and mobilization regimen -Outcome measures including V AS, International Knee Documentation Committee questionnaire (IKDC), and knee flexion ROM were evaluated after the surgery, after 4 weeks, and after 14 weeks from the surgery -The V AS, IKDC score, and knee flexion increased in both groups over time, but the amount of improvement did not differ between the two groups -No additional improvement in the group receiving TENS with exercise was found  –Authors of an RCT (N = 148) compared the efficacy of therapeutic ultrasound combined with TENS versus therapeutic ultrasound alone for pain relief and functional improvement in patients with symptomatic knee OA(44) -Patients either received ultrasound combined with TENS or ultrasound in a supine position for 10 minutes per session for 2 weeks (10 sessions) -Pain score and gait speed were measured prior to treatment and on day 10. No differences were observed between groups for total pain score or gait speed -Adding TENS to ultrasound had no additional benefits over ultrasound alone, in patients with symptomatic knee OA –Progressive muscular relaxation exercises were found more effective than TENS for reducing stress level in patients with tension-type  headache (TTH)(26) -Based on an RCT (N = 30 patients with TTH allocated to a group that practiced progressive muscle relaxation exercises or to a group that received TENS) in India -TENS electrodes were placed bilaterally, either on the head at the site of the pain or on the occiput. Treatment was 15 minutes per day for 7 days -Outcomes measured were pain intensity with V AS and level of stress with Lakaev Academic Stress Response Scale (LASRS) -Pain reduction was not significantly different between the 2 groups -Progressive muscle relaxation exercise was more effective than TENS for reducing stress on the LASRS

Pregnancy/postpartum –Authors of an RCTinvestigated the effects of acu-TENS  with acu-band  (applying TENS over acupuncture points) on nausea, vomiting, retching, and QOL in early pregnant women(51) -Patients in the experimental group received accu TENS with accu band at pressure pointP6 (Neiguan acupuncture point)of their dominant hand. They received treatment at a frequency of 10–15  Hz for 30 minutes a day, 5 days a week for 3 weeks. The acu-band  was continuously applied on the same P6 point with the button pressed for 5 minutes every 2 hours during waking hours for 5 days -The control group received placebo TENS for 30 minutes a day, 5 days a week for 3 weeks. The acu-band  was applied on the dorsum of the wrist and pressure applied for 5 minutes every 2 hours during waking hours for 5 days -After 3 weeks of treatment, the experimental group showed significant improvement in nausea, vomiting and retching, weight gain, and QOL as compared to the control group –TENS was found to reduce postpartum uterine contraction pain during breast-feeding(25) -Based on an RCT (N = 32 postpartum women) in Brazil

Cardiorespiratory/cardiovascular conditionsand TENS –Authors of a study (N = 44) evaluated the effects of TENS on cardiac rhythm and ventricular recovery time by measuring the QT dispersion in patients with pain but no cardiac disease(52) -TENS application to the chest wall is not recommended; therefore, the left shoulder was selected as application site due to its proximity to the heart -TENS application to the left shoulder had no significant effect on the QT interval dispersion measured on ECG -TENS application to the left shoulder is safe in patients with no cardiac disease –TENS was found to alleviate postoperative pain and improve pulmonary function in patients following abdominal surgery(27) -Based on an RCT (N = 48 patients who underwent abdominal surgery) in Japan -Participants were randomized to 3 groups, TENS, placebo TENS, and no TENS (control), and received the intervention for 1 hour a day for 3 days postoperatively. Outcome measures included pulmonary function (vital capacity and cough peak flow, measured with a spirometer) and postoperative pain (V AS) -The TENS group had a significant reduction in pain compared with the placebo TENS and the control group -There was improvement in the pulmonary function of the TENS group at mid intervention and post intervention, but not in the placebo TENS group or the control group –Authors of an RCT (N = 50 patients with stable COPD) in China found that acu-TENS  applied over the EX-B-1 (Dingchuan), BL-13  (Feishu), BL-23  (Shenshu), and ST-36  (Zusanli) acupressure points had improved pulmonary function test, COPD assessment test (CAT), and Dyspnea Visual Analogue scale (DV AS) scores(34) -Patients were randomized to the acu-TENS  group or control group  -Patients in the acu-TENS  group had electrodes placed on the EX-B-1,  BL-13, BL-23,  and ST-36  acupressure points with a frequency of 2Hz. The control group had electrodes placed on the same acupressure points, but with no electrical current -Treatment was 40 minutes, 2 times per week for 7 weeks (total of 14 sessions) -Results: FEV1, CAT, and DV AS improved significantly more in the acu-TENS group than in the controls

Neurological conditions and TENS –Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  evaluated the effect of TENS on spasticity in adults with stroke(47) -TENS along with other physical therapy treatments was more effective in reducing spasticity in the lower limbs compared to placebo TENS -TENS, when administered along with other physical therapy treatments, was effective in reducing spasticity when compared to other physical therapy interventions alone -There is strong evidence that TENS used as an adjunct to exercise helps to manage lower-limb  spasticity in patients with stroke –Authors of arandomized cross-over  trial (N = 10) compared the effects of TENS and functional electrical stimulation (FES) on lower-limb  spasticity in patients with spinal cord injury (SCI)(48) -Each patient received a single session of TENS and of FES on 2 separate days. Spasticity using the Modified Ashworth Scale and the spinal cord assessment tool for spastic reflexes (SCATS) were assessed at baseline, immediately, 1 hour, 4 hours, and 24 hours post intervention -There were no significant differences between FES and TENS. TENS and FES significantly reduced spasticity up to 4 hours in hip adductors and knee extensors. SCATS values showed significant reductions at 1 hourfollowing TENS and 4 hours following FES -These findings suggest that both TENS and FES can be used as a therapeutic adjunct to relieve spasticity –TENS was found to reduce lower-extremity  spasticity in hemiplegic patients(35) -TENS group consisted of 27 patients with spasticity (at least grade 1 on Ashworth Scale) after acute cerebrovascular accident. Control group consisted of 24 healthy persons who did not receive TENS -EMG studies were taken before and after TENS treatment in both groups -Primary outcome measures were the Brunnstrom stage, Ashworth Scale, and 10-meter  walk time -Treatment was a single session of TENS for 30 minutes with electrodes placed on the tibialis nerve. Frequency and duration were set at 50 Hz and 100 msec, respectively, with amplitude not exceeding 50mA -A significant decrease in spasticity levels and an increase in walking speed were found in the TENS group –Authors of an RCT (N = 16 patients with subacute traumatic SCI and spasticity) in Myanmar found that addition of TENS to standard physical therapy reduced spinal spasticity(28) -Patients reported plantar flexor spasticity as painful or limited their daily activity -Participants were randomized to an experimental group that received TENS before physical therapy or to a control group that received conventional physical therapy only -TENS was applied in 60-minute  sessions over the bilateral common peroneal nerve with the patient in a supine position, followed by 30 minutes of physical therapy every weekday for 3 weeks -The control group received the same physical therapy for 30 minutes every weekday for 3 weeks -The primary outcome measure was the composite spasticity score derived from summation of ankle jerk score, muscle tone score, and ankle clonus score -The TENS and physical therapy group had a greater reduction in clinical spasticity over both the immediate and shortterm (3 weeks) than the control group –Authors of an RCT (N = 52 patients with SCI and central pain) in China found that TENS effectively decreased pain(29) -Participants were randomized into an experimental group treated with TENS for 20 minutes 3 times a week for 12 weeks or a control group that received sham TENS for the same amount of time -The primary outcome measure was the MPQ -Results indicated that TENS treatment was more effective for relieving pain than sham TENS

Wound care –Authors of a pilot study (N = 23 inpatients with open wounds) in the United States found that high-intensity  TENS was effective for reducing pain associated with wound care procedures(30) -Participants rated pain intensity during their first dressing change on a numeric scale of 0 to 10  -High-intensity  TENS was applied using 4 square electrodes placed on the top and bottom and both sides of the wound beyond the border of the dressing 30 minutes prior to the dressing change. The amplitude was increased every 5 minutes until the dressing change began and then once during the dressing change to achieve and maintain the strongest tolerable sensation during the wound care procedure -The high-intensity  TENS significantly reduced pain by a mean of 2.0 on the numeric scale. The effect was clinically significant for subjects with severe pain during the first dressing change, but not for subjects with moderate pain

TMD –Authors of a 2014 systematic review found evidence was lacking to recommend TENS for treating TMD(19) –Authors of a 2014 RCT (N = 40 patients with TMD) in India found that TENS was an effective adjuvant modality in the management of TMD pain(31) -Participants were randomly assigned to a group treated with medication alone (analgesics and muscle relaxants) or to a group receiving TENS therapy in combination with medications -Pain was measured using the V AS -Results -Significant reductions in pain were found in both groups -The TENS with medications group had a greater reduction in pain than the medications-only  group –Authors of study (N = 60) compared the effectiveness of TENS and microcurrent nerve stimulation (MENS)in the management of masticatory muscle pain. Patients received either TENS or MENS for 20 minutes a day for 5 consecutive days(46) -TENS and MENS were equally effective in improving functional mouth opening -MENS showed a greater and more immediate effect in pain relief -Both TENS and MENS can be used to effectively treat chronic masticatory muscle pain and decreased functional mouth opening
Phantom limb pain(16) –Authors of a review found evidence was lacking to support the use of TENS to treat phantom limb and stump pain

Acupressure-like  TENS was found to increase the pain threshold of cold-induced  pain when electrodes are placed on the TE5 (Waiguan) and PC6 (Neiguan) acupoints(33) –48 patients were divided into three groups: TENS with electrodes of 1 cm2 area, TENS with electrodes of 15 cm2 area, or placebo group –Study consisted of three phases: cold-induced  pain without TENS, cold-induced pain with TENS or placebo, cold-induced pain post-TENS –Pain was measured using the V AS –Results: the group that received acupressure-like  TENS had a greater cold-induced  pain threshold than the placebo group

Lower urinary tract dysfunction (LUTD) –Authors of a prospective cohort study (N = 33 patients with neurological LUTD) in France found that use of a TENS unit at home was associated with a statistically significant decrease in symptoms of over-active  bladder and dysuria at 2 months follow-up(40) –See Description , Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Acute pain Reduce/eliminate pain TENS _ See Guidelines for use of device/equipment and Treatment summary , aboveN/A Implement a home program to support the desired outcomes, as appropriate and indicated  Chronic pain Reduce/eliminate pain TENS _ See Guidelines for use of device/equipment and Treatment summary , above _ Acupuncture-like TENS might be used for the treatment of chronic pain;(6) however, a review of the literature reports that more research with solid methodology is warranted to better support its efficacy and delineate optimal parameters(3)N/A Implement a home program to support the desired outcomes, as appropriate and indicated Other impairments TENS could potentially be used to treat include reduced motor function, reduced strength, spasticity, and shortness of breathImprove motor function and strength, reduce spasticity and shortness of breathTENS _ Please see Guidelines for use of device/ equipment  and Treatment summary , aboveN/A Implement a home program to support the desired outcomes, as appropriate and indicated Risk factors: The individual might experience skin irritation(6) _ _ Adverse events of TENS are rare(3)Minimize risk of skin irritation and adverse eventsPatient education _ See Contraindications/ precautions , above _ _ Confirm the patient’s sensation is intact _ _ Ensure that the appropriate level of supervision is always provided; if the patient is utilizing the device at home, educate and ensure independence with skin inspections _ _ The patient should be able to shut the device off independentlyN/A N/A .

improve motor function and strength: MMT or other strength measure as indicated by condition
Functional measures as indicated by condition
Reduce spasticity/muscle tone, as indicated Modified Ashworth Scale, deep tendon reflexes, and clonusMaintenance and Prevention

patient education: Patients and their caregivers require complete instructions for home use See TENS and Electrothermal Therapy for Pain Management, WebMD website at https://www.webmd.com/back-pain/guide/electrothermal-therapy See: Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), Cleveland Clinic website at https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/treatments/15840-transcutaneous-electrical-nerve-stimulation-tens Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
